template.arg: Actor, writer, composer, musician, comedian, artist, ornithologist, conservationist, television presenter

article.paragraph: William Edgar "Bill" OddieOrder of the British EmpireOBELondon Gazette5696314 June 200312yes(born 7 July 1941) is an English writer, composer, musician, comedian, artist, ornithologist, conservationist and television presenter. He became famous as one ofThe Goodies.

ABirdwatchingbirdwatchersince his childhood inQuinton, Birmingham,cite bookOne Flew Into the Cuckoo's EggOddieWilliam2009Hodder Paperbacks978-0-340-95194-1http://books.google.co.uk/books?id5 January 2012Oddie has established a reputation as anornithologist, conservationist, and television presenter onwildlifeissues. Some of his books are illustrated with his own paintings and drawings.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/alabaster/A32619233Bill Oddie OBE – Comedian and NaturalistBBC15 July 2014His wildlife programmes for theBBCinclude:SpringwatchSpringwatch/Autumnwatch,Bill Oddie's How to Watch WildlifeHow to Watch Wildlife,Wild In Your Garden,Birding with Bill Oddie,Britain Goes Wild with Bill OddieandBill Oddie Goes Wild.
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Oddie's father was assistant chief accountant at the Midlands Electricity Board.InterviewSunday TimesMoney p14, 29 March 2015His mother was diagnosed withschizophrenia, and during most of his youth lived in a hospital.The One Show, 13 February 2012He was educated at Lapal Primary School, Halesowen Grammar School (nowEarls High SchoolThe Earls High School,Halesowen) andKing Edward's School, Birmingham, an all-boysIndependent school (United Kingdom)independent school, where he captained the school'srugby unionteam.cite newshttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2082578/Bill-Oddie-remembers-answering-school-eventually-prefect.htmlMe and my school photo: Bill Oddie remembers answering back and eventually becoming a prefectDaily MailPeterRobertson5 January 20121 December 2013He then studiedEnglish LiteratureatPembroke College, CambridgePembroke College,University of Cambridge.
article.heading: Career
Comedy
article.paragraph: Whilst at Cambridge University Oddie appeared in severalFootlightsFootlights Clubproductions. One of these, arevuecalledA Clump of Plinths, was so successful at theEdinburgh Festival Fringethat it was renamedCambridge Footlights RevueCambridge Circusand transferred to the West End in London, thenNew ZealandandBroadway theatreBroadwayin September 1964. Meanwhile, still at Cambridge, Oddie wrote scripts for and appeared briefly in TV'sThat Was The Week That Was.cite webhttp://www.dfmanagement.tv/Bill_Oddie.html Bill Oddie David Foster Management 9 October 2010

He appeared inBernard Braden's television seriesOn The Braden Beatin 1964. Subsequently, he was a key member of the performers in theBBCradio seriesI'm Sorry, I'll Read That Again(ISIRTA; 1965), where many of his musical compositions were featured. Some were released on the albumDistinctly Oddie(Polydor, 1967). He was one of the first performers toparodya rock song, arranging the traditionalYorkshirefolk song "On Ilkla Moor Baht'at" in the style ofJoe Cocker's hit rendition ofthe Beatles' "With a Little Help from My Friends" (released onJohn Peel'sDandelion Recordsin 1970 and featured in Peel's special box of most-treasured singles), and singing "Andy Pandy" in the style of a brassy soul number such asWilson PickettorGeno Washingtonmight perform. In many shows he would do short impressions ofHughie Green.

On television Oddie was co-writer and performer in the comedy seriesTwice a FortnightwithGraeme Garden,Terry Jones,Michael PalinandJonathan Lynn. Later, he was co-writer and performer in the comedy seriesBroaden Your MindwithTim Brooke-Taylorand Graeme Garden, for which Oddie became a cast member for the second series.

Oddie, Brooke-Taylor and Garden then co-wrote and appeared in their television comedy seriesThe Goodies (TV series)The Goodies. The Goodies also released records, including "Father Christmas Do Not Touch Me"/"The In-Betweenies", "Funky Gibbon", and "Black Pudding Bertha", which were hit singles in 197475. They reformed, briefly, in 2005, for a successful 13-date tour of Australia.

Oddie, Brooke-Taylor and Garden voiced characters on the 1983 animated children's programmeBananaman.cite webhttp://www.80scartoons.co.uk/bananaman2.php"Bananaman" – 80s Cartoons80scartoons.co.uk4 February 201215 July 2014cite webhttp://www.internationalhero.co.uk/b/banaman.htmBananaman – International HeroInternationalhero.co.uk15 July 2014cite webhttp://www.johnnorrisbrown.com/classic-nick/bananaman/index.htm"Bananaman" – Classic Nick OnlineJohnnorrisbrown.com15 July 2014

In the Amnesty International showA Poke in the Eye (With a Sharp Stick), Oddie, Brooke-Taylor and Garden sang their hit song "Funky Gibbon". They also appeared onTop of the Popswith the song. Together with Garden (who is a qualified doctor), Oddie co-wrote many episodes of the television comedy seriesDoctor in the House (TV series)Doctor in the House, including most of the first season and all of the second season. He has occasionally appeared on the BBC Radio 4 panel gameI'm Sorry I Haven't a Clue, on which Garden and Brooke-Taylor are regular panellists. In 1982 Garden and Oddie wrote, but did not perform in, a 6-part science fiction sitcom calledAstronauts (television)AstronautsforCentral Independent TelevisionCentralandITV (TV network)ITV. The show was set in an internationalspace stationin the near future.British Comedy Guidesitcomsitcoms/astronauts.shtmlAstronauts
article.heading: Natural history
article.paragraph: Oddie's first published work was an article about the birdlife of Birmingham'sBartley Reservoirin theWest Midland Bird Club's 1962 Annual ReportCite journalOddieW.E.July 1963Birds in the Bartley Reservoir Area, 1931-1962 (Part I)The West Midland Bird Report, 1962[[West Midland Bird Club]]Birmingham29http://www.westmidlandbirdclub.com/archive/bartley-62.htm13 February 2010http://web.archive.org/web/20110514235149/http://www.westmidlandbirdclub.com/archive/bartley-62.htm14 May 2011(he is first credited in the 1956 report, in which reports of his bird observations are tagged with his initials "WEO"Cite episodeBill Oddie – Bird WatcherITV Central30 July 1985Nature WatchCite journalJuly 1957The West Midland Bird Report, 1956[[West Midland Bird Club]]Birmingham23http://www.westmidlandbirdclub.com/archive/reports1950s#R19564 January 2013Annual Report, 1950shttp://web.archive.org/web/20130602102919/http://www.westmidlandbirdclub.com/archive/reports1950s#R19562 June 2013). He has since written a number of books about birds and birdwatching, as well as articles for many specialist publications includingBritish Birds (Magazine)British Birds,Birdwatching MagazineandBirdwatch.

He discussed bird song recordings with Derek Jones in an August 1973BBC Radio 4programme calledSounds Natural.Radio Timesentry forCite episodeSounds Natural12 September 2013[[BBC Radio]][[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]]13 August 1973

In the autumn of 1976 Oddie was involved in the successful identification of Britain's first ever record ofPallas's Reed BuntingonFair Isle, Shetland.cite bookFirst for Britain and Ireland 1600–1999PhilipPalmerArlequin PressChelmsford20001-900159-41-4263

One of Oddie's first forays in the world of television natural history was as a guest onAnimal Magic (TV series)Animal Magicin December 1977.Radio Timesentry forCite episode[[Animal Magic (TV series)|Animal Magic]]12 September 2013[[BBC Television]][[BBC One]]13 December 1977Another early natural history radio appearance was in October, as the guest on Radio 4'sThrough My Window, discussing the birds ofHampstead Heath.Radio Timesentry forCite episodeThrough My Window12 September 2013[[BBC Radio]][[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]]11 October 1978

In 30 July 1985, he was the subject of a 50-minuteNature Watch Special: Bill Oddie  Bird Watcher, in which he was interviewed byJulian PettiferCite newshttp://web6.infotrac.galegroup.com/itw/infomark/359/357/47201865w16/purlChoice (Today's Television Programmes)LawsonMark30 July 1985The TimesUK2912 November 2008at places where he had spent time birding, including Bartley Reservoir, theChristopher Cadbury Wetland ReserveatUpton Warren,RSPB Titchwell MarshandBlakeney Point.

Oddie has since hosted a number of successful nature programmes for the BBC, many produced byStephen Moss, including:cite webhttp://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/1166900/credits.htmlBill Oddie: Film & TV Creditswww.screenonline.org.uk12 November 2008

article.paragraph: On its first evening of broadcast in 2004,Britain Goes Wildset a record for its timeslot of 8 pm onBBC Twoof 3.4 million viewers, one million more than theChannel 4programme showing at that time.Britain Goes Wild, renamedSpringwatchthe following year, became a wildlife broadcasting phenomenon, attracting up to 5 million viewers.Citation neededJanuary 2010

He became president of theWest Midland Bird Clubin 1999,cite webhttp://www.westmidlandbirdclub.com/club/chrono#C1990sWest Midland Bird Club: ChronologyWest Midland Bird Club25 April 2010http://web.archive.org/web/20100420121931/http://www.westmidlandbirdclub.com/club/chrono#C1990s20 April 2010having been Vice-President since 1991,and is a former member of the council of theRSPB. Oddie is also a vice-president of theLeague Against Cruel Sportscite webhttp://www.league.org.uk/content/494/Celebrity-SupportCelebrities who support the League Against Cruel SportsLeague Against Cruel Sports8 November 2012and a vice-president of theBTCVBritish Trust for Conservation Volunteers.BTCV - Who we areHe practised as aBird ringingbird ringer, but allowed his licence to lapse.

In 2003 Oddie set up amarathonhalf-marathonto raise money for various wildlife charities in his birth-town ofRochdale.cite webhttp://www.rochdale.towntalk.co.uk/local/famous-people/d/600/bill-oddie/Bill Oddie of RochdaleTownTalk17 June 2014Celebrities who have participated in the event includeRay Mears,Catherine JenkinsandHugh Fearnley-Whittingstall.

In 2011, Oddie featured as an investigator inSnares Uncovered: killers in the countryside.cite webhttp://www.onekind.org/take_action/campaigns/snare_free/snares_uncovered/Snares Uncoveredonekind.org15 March 2012The film carried out an expose of snaring in Scotland and was commissioned by animal protection charityOneKind. During the investigation, Oddie discovered over 70 snare traps and several stink pits.
article.heading: Music
article.paragraph: Oddie wrote original music atThe University of CambridgeCambridge Universityfor theFootlightsand later wrote comic songs forI'm Sorry, I'll Read That Again. He also wrote a number of comic songs forThe Goodies, most of them performed by Oddie.

In the 1960s and early 1970s, Oddie released a number of singles and at least one album. One of the former, issued in 1970 onJohn Peel'sDandelion Recordslabel (Catalogue No: 4786), wasOn Ilkla Moor Baht 'at,cite webhttp://eil.com/shop/moreinfo.asp?catalogideil.comeil.com12 June 2009performed in the style ofJoe Cocker'sWith a Little Help from my Friends. The B-side,Harry Krishna, featured theHare Krishna (mantra)Hare Krishnachant, substituting the names of contemporary famous people called Harry, includingHarry Secombe,Harry Worth,Harry Lauder, andHarry Corbett, as well aspunssuch as "Harry [Hurry] along now", "Harrystotle [Aristotle]" and ending with "Harry-ly [I really] must go now". Both tracks appear on the compilation CDLife Too, Has Surface Noise: The Complete Dandelion Records Singles Collection 19691972(2007).

He played the drums andsaxophoneand appeared as Cousin Kevin in a production ofThe Who's rock operaTommy (rock opera)Tommyat theRainbow Theatre,Finsbury Park, Londonon 9 December 1972. He has also contributed vocals to aRick Wakemanalbum,Criminal Record.

Oddie took part in theEnglish National Operaproduction of theGilbert and Sullivancomic operaThe Mikado, in which he appeared in the role of the "Lord High Executioner", taking over the role fromEric Idle. During the early 1990s, Oddie was a DJ for London-basedjazzradio station102.2 Jazz FM.Citation neededMay 2010

In 2007 Oddie appeared on the BBC seriesPlay It Again.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/music/playitagain/programmes/series1/billoddiePlay It Again: Bill Oddie grapples with the electric guitarBBCIn the episode he attempts to realise his dream of becoming arock guitarist. Initially teacherBridget Mermikidestries to teach him using traditional methods but he rebels: instead he turns to old friendsAlbert Lee,Dave Davies(ofThe Kinks) andMark Knopflerfor advice and strikes out on his own. He succeeds in the target of playing lead guitar for his daughter Rosie's band at her 21st birthday party, and even manages to impress his erstwhile teacher.

In November 2010, he agreed, along with fellow members ofThe Goodies, to re-release their 1970s hit The Funky Gibbon to raise funds for theInternational Primate Protection League's Save the Gibbon appeal.
article.heading: Other television and audio appearances
article.paragraph: Oddie appeared as the hapless window cleaner in theEric Sykes' comedy storyThe Plank (1967 film)The Plankin 1967. He also presented the live children's Saturday morning entertainment showSaturday Banana(ITV (TV network)ITV/Southern Television) during the late 1970s. In the late 1980s he was a presenter of the BBC TV showFax (TV show)Fax(a show about 'facts').

In 1981 he appeared as aTelethon#New ZealandTelethoncelebrity in New Zealand, hosted byTV One (New Zealand)TV1.cite webhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/sunday-star-times/features/profiles/637257/An-Oddie-but-a-GoodieAn Oddie, but a Goodie20 September 2008Sunday Star TimesHe voicesAsterixin the UK dub of the 1989 animated filmAsterix and the Big Fight (film)Asterix and the Big Fight(an animated adaptation of the booksAsterix and the Big FightandAsterix and the Soothsayer, novelized asOperation Getafix).

In the 1990s he became better known as a presenter of birdwatching, and later wildlife-related, programmes such asSpringwatch. Although he remains almost unknown to US audiences, in 1992 he was a guest star in the US comedy television seriesMarried... with Childrenfor a 3-part episode set in England."Married...With Children."BBC Guide to Comedy (Retrieved on: 30 July 2007)
In 199798 he appeared on theChannel 4archaeological programmeTime Team, as the team excavated a Roman villa site inTurkdean, Gloucestershire.

He was the compre of a daytime BBCgameshowHistory Hunt(in 2003); and has appeared in theDoctor Whoaudio dramaDoctor Who and the Pirates. In 2004, he appeared in the BBC showWho Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)Who Do You Think You Are?, in which he looked into his ancestry he was visibly moved by its revelations. In 2005, he took part inRolf on Artthe big event at Trafalgar Squareand in September that year was also a celebrity guest along withLynda Bellinghamon theITV1programmeWho Wants to be a Millionaire.

In 2006 Oddie appeared in the BBC showNever Mind The Buzzcocks,cite webhttp://news.independent.co.uk/people/profiles/article2636212.eceJupitus comments on Oddie's appearance on 'Never Mind The Buzzcocks'News.independent.co.uk19 March 201415 July 2014and also appeared on the topical quiz show8 out of 10 Cats. He was also the voice behind manyB&Qadverts throughout 2006/2007. On 25 May 2007, Oddie made acameo appearanceonRonni Ancona's new comedysketch show,Ronni Ancona & Co.

He hosted thegenealogy-based seriesMy Famous Family, broadcast onUKTV Historyin 2007. In 2008, Oddie was a guest onJamie Oliver's television specialJamie's Fowl Dinners, talking about free-range chickens. He also recorded a voice for Lionhead Studios'Fable II.Citation neededJanuary 2010

He also appeared onWould I Lie to You? (TV series)Would I Lie To You?in 2011 where he revealed that he was saved from drowning byFreddy MarksFreddyfrom popular children's seriesRainbow (TV series)RainbowandRod, Jane and Freddywhile on holiday in theSeychelles.File:Bill Oddie Live (Perth June 27 2013).jpgthumbBill Oddie performing live at the Astor Theatre in Perth, Western Australia, 27 June 2013.
In February 2015, Oddie appeared inThe Keith Lemon Sketch Showas the narrator of the sketchEd SheeranWatch.
He appeared as a contestant on a celebrity edition ofFifteen to Onein August 2015.
article.heading: 2013 Australian tour
article.paragraph: Oddie undertook anAustraliantour during June 2013 in all of the mainland states capital citiesBrisbane,Sydney,Melbourne,AdelaideandPerthin a series of one-off shows, "An Oldie but a Goodie". A video message from Tim Brooke-Taylor and Graeme Garden was shown during the performances.cite webhttp://www.billoddietour.com.au/shows.htmlAn Oldie but a GoodieBilloddietour.com.au15 July 2014Oddie made personal appearances on bothThe Project (TV program)The ProjectandAdam Hills TonightTV shows during the tour.
article.heading: Personal life
Family
article.paragraph: In 1967 Oddie married Jean Hart,Hampstead marriage register 1967 Oct-Dec vol. 5b p1372cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/mar/27/bill-oddie-my-family-valuesBill Oddie: My family valuesAngelaWintleThe Guardian27 March 20159 July 2015and from this marriage he has two daughters, Bonnie Oddie andKate Hardie, an actress, as well as three grandchildren, Lyle, Ella, and Gracie.

In 1983 he married Laura Beaumont-Giles,Camden marriage register 1983 JulSep vol.14 p1900with whom he has worked on a variety of projects for children, including film scripts, drama and comedy series, puppet shows and books. They have a daughter, Rosie, born in October 1985,Camden birth register 1985 November vol. 14 p1828Cite newshttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1048416/My-Oddie-life-The-troubled-times-Wildlife-Bill.htmlMy very Oddie life: the troubled times of Wildlife BillThe Daily Mail29 August 2008London(mentions Rosie's birth "the night before Halloween")and live inHampstead, North London. Rosie Oddie is a musician, also using the name Rosie Bones.cite webBands in Transithttp://bandsintransit.com/artists/view/57/BIGkids18 September 2012
article.heading: Depression and bipolar disorder
article.paragraph: Oddie has suffered fromMood disorderdepressionfor most of his life and was diagnosed withMajor depressive disorderclinical depressionin 2001.Cite newshttp://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,,1885499,00.htmlThe GuardianLondon26 April 2010I couldn't move. I was catatonicOn 11 March 2009 it was reported that he had been admitted to Capio Nightingalepsychiatric hospitalinMarylebone, to deal with his depression. His then agent David Foster said: "Bill gets these bouts every two or three years where he gets down for about two weeks and recovers. He sometimes goes into hospital or takes a break or has a change of scenery to recharge his batteries."Cite newsThe Telegraphhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/4973166/TV-presenter-Bill-Oddie-admitted-to-hospital-with-clinical-depression.htmlTV presenter Bill Oddie admitted to hospital with clinical depression11 March 2009LondonOliverGregory26 April 2010In January 2010 Oddie spoke to the media, revealing that he had in fact had two separate stays in different hospitals, only being discharged "in time for Christmas". He said that he was dealing with depression andbipolar disorder, describing the period as "probably the worst 12 months of my life". Oddie stated that he was planning to meet with BBC executives to discuss his return to television work.Cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8448164.stmBill Oddie speaks about his depression battleBBC News8 January 2010Cite newshttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1241338/Bill-Oddie-reveals-feared-depression-kill-worst-12-months-life.htmlBill Oddie feared depression would kill him after 'the worst 12 months of my life'The Daily MailGeorginaLittlejohn8 January 2010London

His illness meant that Oddie did not appear in the 2009 and 2010 series ofSpringwatch, although he made a guest appearance in the penultimate episode of the latter. He subsequently claimed he wasDismissal (employment)dismissedfromSpringwatchand that this had caused the depressive illness.citation neededApril 2015

Oddie presented theBBC Radio 4Appeal programme on 10 August 2014 on behalf of theCharitable organizationcharityBipolar UK. He revealed that as a consequence of his bipolar disorder he had attemptedsuicideduring one of his depressive episodes.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04d0x5mRadio 4 Appealbbc.co.uk10 August 201414 August 2014On the UK TV programWho Do You Think You Are?he attributed his depression and bipolar disorder as an adult to his minimal and painful relationship with his mother.citation neededMay 2015
article.heading: Political views
article.paragraph: Oddie supports theGreen Party of England and WalesGreen Party.cite newsOddieBillhttps://twitter.com/BillOddie/status/524630988505509888https://twitter.com/BillOddie/status/52463098850550988826 October 2014[[Twitter]]21 October 2014In October 2014, on the BBC'sSunday Morning Live (BBC)Sunday Morning Live, he stated that he wanted a limit on the number of children that British families can have, saying that he was "very often ashamed" to be British, whom he called "a terrible race".cite newsAlexanderEllaBill Oddie suggests that large British families should be 'contained'http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/bill-oddie-suggests-that-large-british-families-should-be-contained-9804704.html26 October 2014The Independent19 October 2014cite newsFifieldNicolaBill Oddie says large British families need to be 'contained'http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/immigration/11172446/Bill-Oddie-says-large-British-families-need-to-be-contained.html26 October 2014The Daily Telegraph
article.heading: Honours
article.paragraph: In 2001, Oddie became the third person to decline to appear onThis Is Your Life (UK TV series)This Is Your Life. He changed his mind a few hours later and agreed to appear on the show. On 16 October 2003, Oddie was made anOrder of the British EmpireOBEfor his service to Wildlife Conservation in a ceremony atBuckingham Palace. He played down the event, choosing to wear a camouflage shirt and crumpled jacket to receive his medal. In June 2004, Oddie andJohnny Morriswere jointly profiled in the first of a three partBBC Twoseries,The Way We Went Wild, about television wildlife presenters. In May 2005, he received theBritish Naturalists' Association'sPeter ScottMemorial Award, from BNA presidentDavid Bellamy, "in recognition of his great contribution to our understanding of natural history and conservation."cite newshttp://prnewswire.co.uk/cgi/news/release?idBill Oddie to receive Peter Scott Memorial AwardPR Newswire Europe Ltd.26 April 200515 March 2012cite webhttp://www.bna-naturalists.org/peter.htm#psmThe Peter Scott Memorial AwardBritish Naturalists' Association15 March 2012He is a recipient of theRoyal Society for the Protection of Birds#RSPB MedalRSPB Medal.cite webhttp://www.birdwatch.co.uk/channel/newsitem.asp?cIndependent journalist wins RSPB medalBirdwatch10 October 2011
On 30 June 2009, he was proposed for inclusion in theBirmingham Walk of Stars, with the public invited to vote.cite webhttp://www.walkofstars.net/?catVote for Stars30 June 200925 July 2009
